* The present invention provides a design rule checking system and method that accurately reports appropriate errors for appropriate regions in a system that includes two different kinds of circuits, such as memory and logic.
* The system and method eliminates false errors caused by design rule checking tools examining regions that are not subject to the same design rules supported by the tool.
* The system and method creates customized rules appropriate for different types of memory regions, based on modifying a standard logic rule by pushing more liberal memory based parameter onto stricter logic based parameter.
* The system and method provides a solution to the disadvantages of the first and second conventional methods of checking design rules.
* The system and method simplifies the process of checking design rules by creating customized rules based on modifying a standard set of Logic Rules.
* The system and method ensures accurate resolution of design rules for a system on chip integrated circuit design.
* The system and method eliminates the need for manual checking and cooperation between IC designer, foundry field support engineers, and foundry itself.
* The system and method provides a more reliable and efficient design verification tool for mixed circuit types, such as logic and memory.

* The invention relates to a dynamoelectric machine rotor test apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors, including a test head and a retraction and drive mechanism. * The test head includes a core of magnetic material, a set of primary windings for exciting the rotor, and a skew pick-up coil for sensing the rotor's skew. * The test apparatus includes a sample and hold circuit for acquiring data from the rotor, a phase lock loop for generating timing pulses, and a data processor for processing the data. * The apparatus also includes a control processor for controlling the retraction and drive mechanism and determining the resistance, reactance, and skew values. * The apparatus is particularly useful for non-destructive testing of squirrel cage rotors, including the determination of resistance, reactance, and skew values, and statistical analysis of the data. * The apparatus is designed to be used with a dual test fixture, allowing for efficient testing of multiple rotors simultaneously.

* The source document describes a system and method for managing and securing mobile devices, including the validation of software libraries and the verification of managed applications.

* The invention provides an identification card with an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between two protective, non-rigid layers, encased in a polymer layer. * The card is constructed with a silica-filled polyolefin core layer and polyester bottom layer, sandwiched between two polymer layers. * The core layer is pre-shrunk to minimize damage from bending stresses, and the antenna and chip are embedded in the core layer. * The card is laminated with a polyester laminate on both sides, and a dye diffusion thermal transfer receiver coating is applied to the adhesive side. * Personalization features, such as inkjet receiver coatings and security features, are added to the top surface of the card.

* The invention addresses the problem of implementing a FIFO queue in functional memories, specifically by using a tree-shaped data structure.
* The solution involves adding a header node to the memory structure, which indicates the end and beginning of the queue.
* The header node is used to copy the queue in a constant time and space, making updates faster than in the basic embodiment.
* The header node also indicates the direction of the queue, allowing for inversion of the queue.
* The invention can be implemented as a mirror image, where the node added last is obtained first in a postorder and the one to be deleted next is obtained first in a preorder.
* The header node can be added to the memory structure, and the updates are made faster and less space-consuming than in the basic embodiment.
* The invention can be modified to use a bit to indicate the direction of the queue, allowing for inversion of the queue.
* The invention can be used as a double-ended queue, allowing for both additions and deletions from the beginning and end of the queue.
* The invention can be implemented in a memory arrangement with a header node, maintaining a queue in a tree structure.
* The invention can be used in functional memories, where the queue is implemented using pointers to records.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>
The primary objective of the invention is to provide practical methods for building embedded EPROM devices using existing IC manufacture technologies. The invention aims to provide EPROM devices for DRAM redundancy circuits and EPROM devices manufactured by standard logic technologies. The invention also seeks to eliminate the need for high voltages for operations, making it more cost-effective and reducing the complexity of manufacturing processes.

• The invention provides a method for determining feedback gains in feedback control, which permits determining the proper value of feedback gain both easily and accurately, in a short period of time and irrespective of the kind of the subject of control.
• The method comprises a first step of provisionally determining a predetermined value of a feedback gain, a second step of executing feedback control by using the provisionally determined feedback gain, a third step of detecting an error between a designated value and an actual value of the subject of control during the execution of the second step, a fourth step of calculating an evaluation value indicative of the character of feedback control according to the error detected in the third step, a fifth step of executing the second to fourth steps repeatedly a plurality of times after provisionally determining a new feedback gain value different from the previous value, and a sixth step of calculating a feedback gain value which can provide for a suitable evaluation value according to the relation between the feedback gain value and the evaluation value obtained through the fifth step.
• The method permits a feedback gain providing for a suitable evaluation value to be calculated on the basis of the relation between feedback gain value and evaluation value, and it is thus possible to determine a feedback gain which can realize a suitable feedback control characteristic quickly and reliably.

• The invention provides a zoom lens with a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and a standard image angle at the wide angle end with a reduced total length while still achieving high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.
• The invention comprises a first lens unit with a positive refractive power for focusing, a second lens unit with a negative refractive power for varying the image magnification, a third lens unit with a negative refractive power for compensating for the shift of an image plane, a fourth lens unit with a positive refractive power for making the diverging light beam from the third lens unit an almost parallel light beam, and a fifth lens unit with a positive refractive power for image forming and having lenses of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive, and positive powers in this order.
• The invention achieves high correction of aberrations for high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range by satisfying the conditions for the construction and arrangement of the fourth and fifth lens units.
• The invention is achieved by constructing the fourth and fifth lens units in a bi-convex lens form with a rear surface of strong curvature toward the rear, and the fifth lens unit comprises a bi-convex first lens with a front surface having a stronger curvature than the rear surface, a negative meniscus-shaped second lens of forward convexity, a positive third lens with a front surface of strong curvature toward the front, a negative meniscus-shaped fourth lens of forward convexity, a bi-convex fifth lens with a rear surface of strong curvature, and a positive sixth lens with a front surface of strong curvature toward the front.
• The invention achieves high correction of longitudinal and lateral chromatic aberrations in good balance by designing the fourth and fifth lens units in such a way that the residual aberrations, for example, spherical aberration and inward coma from the zonal to the marginal region of the picture frame, of the zoom section are corrected entirely in good balance.
• The invention achieves high correction of astigmatism without causing other aberrations, mainly coma, to be produced as far as possible by designing the fourth and fifth lens units in such a way that the residual aberrations, for example, spherical aberration and inward coma from the zonal to the marginal region of the picture frame, of the zoom section are corrected entirely in good balance.

<summary>**Summary of the Invention**</summary>
- The invention aims to provide a method and device for detecting elementary particles, enabling both detection and integration of individual signals or pulses, without knowing in advance signal rates or expected counts.
- The invention utilizes a fast, first amplifier followed by a capacitor for amplifying individual signals and integrating signals in a second, slow amplifier.
- It offers a support capacitor to separate signals into overlapping ranges for precise measurement and integration.
- The method and device are applicable in particle accelerators, reactor installations, diagnostic devices, and X-ray and CT devices.
- The invention is particularly useful for detecting charged particles and uncharged particles, with the latter being coated with a converter material for detection.
- The method and device can be used for both individual signals or pulses and their integration, enabling reliable detection and measurement of small-size signals.
- The invention is optimized for read-out performance and can be used for both individual particle detection and particle beam intensity measurement.
- The method and device can be adapted for medical applications, such as particle beam monitoring and imaging processes.
- The invention is applicable in electrical power engineering, including reactor development and diagnostics.

<summary>TECHNICAL FIELD</summary>
- The invention relates to a mobile identification transmitter for activating a security system of a motor vehicle, particularly an access and/or ignition control system, having a housing in which electronics and a communication means are arranged, wherein the communication means can be brought into communication with a communication means of the security system located on board the motor vehicle.

<summary>BACKGROUND</summary>
- DE 10 2010 061 331.2 discloses a keyless security system of a motor vehicle. In this case, the authorized user can actively operate the mobile identification transmitter in order to transmit a signal to the base station, for example a receiver unit included in the motor vehicle, to unlock/lock the motor vehicle.

<summary>INVENTION</summary>
- The invention addresses the problem of creating a mobile identification transmitter for a keyless activation of a security system of a motor vehicle which possesses an enlarged functionality and has a simple design, wherein at the same time the user is provided with a comfortable mobile identification transmitter.

<summary>PROBLEMS</summary>
- The problem addressed by the present invention is that of creating a mobile identification transmitter for a keyless activation of a security system of a motor vehicle which possesses an enlarged functionality and has a simple design, wherein at the same time the user is provided with a comfortable mobile identification transmitter.

<summary>ADVANTAGES</summary>
- The invention provides a payment element that can be removed from the housing of the identification transmitter by the user if necessary, and a closure that protects and seals the receptacle.

<summary>FUNCTIONALITY</summary>
- The invention includes a payment element that can be removed from the housing of the identification transmitter by the user if necessary, and a closure that protects and seals the receptacle.

<summary>ADVANCED FEATURES</summary>
- The invention includes a chip microprocessor in the payment element, which can carry out payment actions with the payment system, and a carrier that can be included in the identification transmitter.

<summary>CONCLUSION</summary>
- The invention provides a mobile identification transmitter that can be used for a keyless activation of a security system of a motor vehicle, which possesses an enlarged functionality and has a simple design, wherein at the same time the user is provided with a comfortable mobile identification transmitter.

<summary>**Summary of the Invention****

The invention provides a system and method for locating and tracing concealed, elongated, conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, in the presence of an adjacent object. The system includes a transmitter and a receiver, with the transmitter inducing alternating currents in the objects and the receiver sensing magnetic fields associated with these currents. The system is particularly useful when a second object is adjacent to the first, and the null output signal characteristic is distorted when another object is present. The invention improves the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing one concealed object over a pair of adjacent objects, such as pipes or cables.

The invention provides a cover plate device that can be installed over a wall-mounted electrical wiring device and is quickly and easily removable. It includes a two-part attachment member with a symmetrical attachment surface and a cover plate member with no fastener holes. The cover plate can be positioned over a wall-mounted wiring device with the attachment member separated to allow viewing of the assembly. The cover plate can be installed using available fasteners and can be easily removed or removed. The invention overcomes the difficulties of prior art devices by providing a cover plate device that is fastened to the wiring device and can be easily removed or installed.

• The present invention provides a solution in the packet domain for integrating voice calls with multimedia sessions as a blended call.
• The blended call is a call that blends voice and multimedia functions into a single communication session.
• The present invention takes an incoming call from a remote caller and routes it to a multimedia server, initiating two parallel components: voice and multimedia.
• The multimedia server manages the signaling paths of the parallel components to control the bearer paths and route the voice component back to the telephony server.
• The multimedia server also handles the multimedia component, passing the signaling paths through and controlling the bearer paths.
• The multimedia server may include a loopback signal or indication to prevent infinite loops between the telephony server and the blender.

* The present invention discloses a method and apparatus for the dicing of semiconductor wafers using pressure to mechanically separate individual die from the wafer without the use of a wafer saw. * The method includes forming trenches along the scribe lines on the wafer and applying a mechanical pressure to the wafer to singulate the individual die. * The apparatus comprises a pad for supporting the wafer and a positioning member to position the wafer on the pad. * The pressure mechanism is used to apply the mechanical pressure to the wafer, causing a "clean break" along the scribe lines to singulate the individual die.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>
* The present invention is directed to a novel protection structure for preventing burnout damage to field emission elements in a field emission display device.
* The protection structure includes at least one reduction plate or electrode on the cathode, typically on the field emission elements, to deflect the discharge path of gas ions away from the cathode.
* The protection structure prevents surges in electrical current from being drawn to the cathode and inducing burnout damage to field emission elements.
* The protection structure includes multiple reduction plates or electrodes interspersed among field emission elements on the cathode to alter the discharge path of ionized gases and prevent current-induced burnout damage to the field emission elements.
* The protection structure is arranged in a meshwork- or net-shaped configuration among field emission elements in the device.
* The protection structure is preferably elongated and runs parallel and adjacent to rows of field emission elements in the device.
* The protection structure is preferably formed on the cathode plate at the same as the cathode strips on the cathode plate.
* The protection structure is preferably formed on the cathode plate and separated from the cathode strips by an insulation layer.
* The protection structure is preferably formed on the cathode plate and separated from the cathode strips by an insulator layer.

* The invention addresses the issue of minimizing total power consumption in home networks by enabling network administrators to transfer network administrative functions from master devices to slave devices.
* The method involves receiving instructions to enter into a power management state, sending data enabling network administrative functions, and placing the master device into the power management state after sending the data.
* The network master node periodically broadcasts a beacon to each device serving as a network slave node, enabling the slave device to start streaming data.
* The network slave node receives a request to transfer a network administrative function from a master device, and the master device transfers the functions to the slave device after receiving the request.
* The network slave node periodically broadcasts a transfer request to the master device, enabling the master device to accept the transfer and perform the network administrative functions.
* The network slave node selects a network slave node to transfer the network administrative functions to based on predetermined criteria, such as network address visibility and network slave node intelligence/functional capabilities.
* The network slave node transfers the network administrative functions to the selected slave network device, which becomes the new master network device and enters into power save mode.
* The network slave node periodically broadcasts a request reply message to the master device, indicating that it has accepted the transfer of network administrative functions.
* The network slave node transfers the network administrative functions to the selected slave network device after the master device accepts the transfer, ensuring that the slave device performs its own nominal device functions.

• The invention addresses the challenge of determining the direction of electromagnetic radiation propagation using antenna elements, particularly focusing on low-elevation angles where ground reflections are difficult to exclude.
• A unique equi-spaced triplet arrangement is identified in U.K. Patent No. 1449196, which optimizes angle measurements by defining fixed angles within the elevation plane.
• The invention extends this concept to optimize angle measurements using the triplet itself, particularly over selected sectors at low elevation angles.
• Measurement of elevation angle is only possible when the signal is non-zero and changes slowly, with angle near its maximum value.
• The array can be used in either receive or transmit mode, with the smallest number of antenna elements possible, optimized for the required sensitivity and accuracy.
• The array is capable of providing unambiguous sector coverage and high angle measurement accuracy over its high amplitude regions.
• The array is suitable for civil and military applications where the elevation angle of an emitting or reflecting object is required.

The invention provides a receiver input circuit with multiple amplification control circuits, including a control loop for amplification control, a second amplification control loop for control signal processing, and a third amplification control loop for signal frequency selective intermediate frequency amplifier. The circuit includes a preamplifier stage, a tunable selective network, a mixer and oscillator stage, and an intermediate frequency filter. The circuit avoids unwanted signal actuation of non-linear components by controlling the amplification of the preamplifier stage and the mixer stage. The circuit also supports the third amplification control circuit by controlling the operating current of the PIN diode. The circuit has advantages in terms of selectivity, signal response threshold, and noise level during control.

* The Downconverting Digitizer of this invention utilizes predictive coding principles to implement a simple down-converting A/D converter.
* By placing the sampler inside the predictive loop, the predictive loop filter can be implemented using DSP techniques, reducing the complexity of the overall converter.
* The predictive loop filter generates a prediction of the input signal, which is then used to construct a digitally represented prediction of the modulated IF input signal.
* The dynamic range performance of the digital predictive encoder is further extended by utilizing the digital output of the loop to generate the signal for controlling a variable gain amplifier placed at the front of the predictive loop input.
* The DC offset performance of the converter is greatly enhanced through incorporation of an offset nuller digital signal processing element which provides an estimate of offsets introduced by various circuits.
* The implementation of the predictive loop allows the predictive filter to be implemented using DSP techniques, reducing the complexity of the overall converter and improving the converter dynamic range and noise performance.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>
The invention provides a dual mode mobile terminal that selectively connects to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN). The WWAN contains a plurality of first base stations, each with a coverage of about 2 to 10 km. The WLAN contains a second base station for gathering service information of the first base stations. The second base station can be an access point with a third network module for demodulating and decoding the broadcasting signals of the first base stations. The mobile terminal has a first wireless module and a second wireless module. When the first wireless module turns off and the second wireless module turns on, the mobile terminal can connect to the WLAN through the second base station. The first wireless module selects a serving base station according to the service information to connect the WWAN. The invention also provides a method for the mobile terminal to select a serving base station in a communication system. The method includes detecting the signal level of the transmitting signal from the second base station to the second wireless module, and selecting a serving base station from the first base stations according to the service information. The method can also include scanning the frequency channels by using the service information. The invention can be used for switching the connecting from WLAN to WWAN in time to avoid dropping or delaying the connections.

• (c) locating said two sub-assemblies in mutually stacked relation, thereby to form a resultant assembly.

<summary>**Summary of the Process for Co-producing Power and Hydrocarbons****

The process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons involves the following steps:

1. **Coal-to-Liquid (CTL) Hydrocarbon Synthesis Facility**
   - **Dry Gasification Stage**: Gasifies coal to produce synthesis gas at elevated pressure.
   - **Gas Clean-up Stage**: Enriches combustion gas with H2 to produce H2-enriched gas.
   - **First Fischer-Tropsch Hydrocarbon Synthesis Stage**: Converts synthesis gas to hydrocarbons.
   - **Second Fischer-Tropsch Hydrocarbon Synthesis Stage**: Converts synthesis gas to hydrocarbons.

2. **Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) Facility**
   - **Wet Gasification Stage**: Gasifies coal to produce combustion gas.
   - **Sour Shift Stage**: Converts combustion gas to synthesis gas precursor.
   - **Hydrogen Enriched Gas Expansion Stage**: Expands synthesis gas precursor to produce hydrogen.
   - **Gas Clean-up Stage**: Cleans combustion gas to remove sulphur, particulate material, and CO2.
   - **First Fischer-Tropsch Hydrocarbon Synthesis Stage**: Converts synthesis gas to hydrocarbons.
   - **Second Fischer-Tropsch Hydrocarbon Synthesis Stage**: Converts synthesis gas to hydrocarbons.

3. **Combustion Gas Expansion Stage**
   - **Combustion Gas Expansion Stage**: Expands combustion gas to produce hot combusted gas.
   - **Gas Combustion and Expansion Stage**: Combusts hot combusted gas to produce power and hot exhaust gas.
   - **Fuel Gas Line**: Combines hot exhaust gas with fuel gas to produce CO2 and hydrocarbons.

4. **Air Separation Unit**
   - **Air Separation Unit**: Separates air into nitrogen and oxygen.
   - **Nitrogen Production Line**: Produces nitrogen.
   - **Water Production Line**: Produces water.
   - **Water Treatment Stage**: Treats water to remove CO2 and water.
   - **CO2 Removal Stage**: Removes CO2 from synthesis gas precursor.
   - **Hydrogen Separation Stage**: Separates hydrogen from synthesis gas precursor.
   - **Hydrogen Recycling Stage**: Recycles hydrogen from the hydrogen separation stage to the first Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stage.
   - **Fuel Gas Line**: Combines hot exhaust gas with fuel gas to produce CO2 and hydrocarbons.

5. **CO2 Removal

The apparatus includes a base structure for stabilization and a clamping arrangement for securely grasping the foam sheet sample without damaging it. • The humidity sensing element for gaseous fluids of the present invention comprises a tubular aluminum first electrode member with an anodized layer impregnated with nickel particles by vacuum deposition, forming a second electrode contacting the ion-forming material and pervious to moisture vapor and disposed on the dielectric coating on the opposite side thereof from the first electrode. The sensor is suitable for excitation by a ten Hertz sine wave alternating current voltage impressed across its electrodes by a solid state electronic measurement circuit and consists essentially of a hollow cylindrical aluminum element with an anodized layer formed by an anodizing bath containing oxalic acid and nickel particles. The sensor is manufactured by a novel combination of familiar and non-exotic manufacturing methods.

* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure, including a drive plate and a shaft, wherein the drive plate has a mounting hole and a shaft fitted to the mounting hole for rotation with the drive plate. The drive plate comprises a body and a coupling formed at the center of the body, the coupling is deeper than the body in the axial direction of the body, the mounting hole being formed in the coupling. The coupling has buffer holes respectively located between adjacent sections. The drive plate has a plurality of protrusions formed on a first side of the body and configured to engage with a driving member, the shaft further comprises a pinion configured to drive a driven member. The drive plate further comprises a plurality of ribs formed at an opposite second side of the body. The mounting hole and the toothed portion are Y-shaped. The drive plate is made of a plastics material. The damper is made of rubber. The shaft further comprises a pinion for driving a gear of a window lift system. The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip located within a groove in the distal end of the toothed portion. The force transmission structure comprises the drive plate and the shaft, and the drive plate is rotated by the damper and the worm gear when the worm gear drives the worm gear. The drive plate drives the shaft to rotate by the Y-shaped mounting hole of the drive plate mating with the Y-shaped toothed portion of the shaft. The drive plate is ideally made of an engineering plastics material with good strength and resistance to impact and can absorb vibration, which is helpful to reduce the noise generated by the gear train.

• The invention involves a multiorifice structure with angularly disposed passages and a method for making the multiorifice structure.
• The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrically shaped members.
• The fused assembly is cut into relatively thin wafers with interstices formed between the fused layers of rods and cylindrical members.
• The thickness of the wafer is determined by the effective aperture of the interstices and is sufficient to impart a directional component parallel to the angular displacement of the rods with respect to the common axis.
• The multiorifice structure can be used for atomizing fuel in automotive fuel injector valves.

* The invention addresses the problem of detecting and eliminating transversely located cigarettes in a cigarette magazine, which is often laborious and costly due to the need to switch off the machine when disruptions occur.

<summary>Summary of the Application</summary>
The application is a continuation of Ser. No. 08/737,546, now U.S. Pat. No. 5,908,332, which was filed on Dec. 12, 1996, and designated the U.S. The application provides a simplified connection system for high voltage cables, including an interface between a cable end and an apparatus or accessory, and an interface between two cable ends or between two apparatuses. The interface is generally applicable, resulting in several advantages such as factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, and simplified field testing. The stress cone design and dimensions are the same for all applications, with variations in diameter of the cable or apparatus entrance. The interface components do not include any gas or oil, and are therefore not prone to leak or explode. The interface components are also easier to expand than the inner cone concept, simplifying complete alignment of meeting surfaces without risking glow discharges. The outer cone concept is preferred over the inner cone concept for its compact design, lower material and installation cost, and complete independence between gas insulated switchgear and cable installations. The invention also includes transformer and out-door terminal versions, and a straight through joint and transition joint between two apparatuses. The application is limited to high voltage installations and is not applicable to SF6 and oil filled apparatuses.

* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet. The contractor team of Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation and Boeing Helicopter Company were expected to design a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of performing the primary missions of armed reconnaissance and attack. Critical to achieving these capabilities are the successful development of advanced technologies, including composite materials, advanced avionics and propulsion systems, and sophisticated software and hardware. The Army must meet ambitious maintainability goals in order to realize significantly lower operating and support costs predicted for this program and achieve a wartime operational availability for the Comanche of 6 hours per day. * The Army's restructuring of the Comanche program continues risks associated with making production decisions before knowing whether the aircraft will be able to perform as required. The Army proposed, and was subsequently granted approval, to buy six "early operational capability" aircraft, in addition to the two prototypes that were to be acquired under the Secretary's decision. According to program officials, these aircraft are estimated to cost in excess of $300 million. The Army does not consider these aircraft as either prototype or low-rate initial production aircraft; however, program officials believe that when these aircraft are fielded, the Army will be able to better evaluate the Comanche's mission capability. * The Comanche was originally justified to the Congress as a relatively inexpensive aircraft. However, since 1985, the program has experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost. Funding reductions have caused the program to undergo significant restructuring, resulting in sharp decreases in planned acquisition quantities and lengthening of development schedules, thereby increasing Comanche program costs. * The Comanche program's uncertainties in software development and aircraft maintainability increase the risk that the aircraft will not perform successfully. We believe the restructuring provides additional time to resolve these issues before the decision to enter production is made. The Comanche will be the most computerized, software-intensive Army helicopter ever built. The Army estimates that about 1.4 million lines of code are required to perform and integrate mission critical functions. With additional ground support and training software to be developed, the total program will have more than 2.7 million lines of code. This compares to about 573,000 lines of code for the upgraded Apache attack helicopter with fire control radar. The Army estimates 95 percent of the Comanche’s total software will be written in Ada, a DOD-developed programming language. The Army plans to demonstrate initial software performance with the mission equipment package

* The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was established in 1976 and amended in 1984 to govern the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal. RCRA governs the identification, listing, and management of hazardous waste, including the identification of waste that should be classified as hazardous.
* Many stakeholders believe that RCRA has accomplished its purpose of minimizing present and future threats to human health and the environment by identifying and listing hazardous waste.
* RCRA contains provisions governing the identification and listing of hazardous waste, including the identification of waste that should be classified as hazardous. For example, EPA has established criteria for identifying waste that should be classified as hazardous.
* RCRA also contains provisions governing the identification and listing of hazardous waste. EPA has established criteria for identifying waste that should be classified as hazardous. For example, EPA has listed specific types of waste that are to be considered hazardous.
* RCRA’s regulations govern all hazardous waste, regardless of where or how it is generated. Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated.
* Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated. • The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing and implementing the ALMRS/Modernization project, which includes a common information technology platform and a land-use plan to balance multiple uses and competing demands.
• The project is estimated to cost $262.8 million from 1983 through April 30, 1995, and is expected to equal the OMB and BLM funding agreement for fiscal years 1983 through 2002.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project includes three components: ALMRS IOC, GCDB, and modernization of BLM's computer and telecommunications infrastructure.
• The ALMRS IOC component supports case processing activities, including recording mining claims, processing mineral patents, and granting rights-of-way for roads and power corridors.
• The GCDB component contains geographic coordinates and survey information for land parcels.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project office is responsible for the ALMRS IOC development and modernization.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project is a large-scale effort to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities, provide information to support land and resource management activities, and modernize BLM's computer and telecommunications infrastructure.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project is expected to provide efficient means to record, maintain, and retrieve land description, ownership, and use information to support BLM, other federal programs, and interested parties.

* The text discusses the impact of mutual funds on deposits and the movement of money from deposits to mutual funds.
* It provides data on mutual fund deposits and mutual fund inflows, comparing them to bank deposits.
* The text notes that mutual funds have attracted sizable amounts of money that otherwise might have been placed in bank deposits.
* It also mentions that mutual funds have further advanced this securitization process.
* The text concludes that the movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds should have little to no effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy, even though this movement may have shifted the intermediaries through which finance flows.
* The text also discusses the impact of mutual funds on the availability of credit for different sectors, including residential, consumer, and business sectors.
* It notes that the movement of money out of deposits and into mutual funds does not necessarily reduce credit availability for any group of borrowers, but there is a possibility that some borrowers from small banks might face credit availability constraints in certain circumstances.

• The source document discusses the importance of single audits in federal grant awards, highlighting the need for improved audit quality and accountability.
• It mentions the Single Audit Act of 1984, which established the concept of a single audit to replace multiple grants with a single audit of an entity as a whole.
• The document notes that the quality of single audits conducted under the act has been a concern since its passage in 1984.
• It provides a detailed analysis of the audit quality issues found in the PCIE study, including the prevalence of acceptable audits, significant deficiencies, and unacceptable audits.
• The document recommends three-pronged approaches to improve single audit quality: revising and improving standards, establishing minimum continuing professional education requirements, and reviewing and enhancing disciplinary processes.
• It concludes by emphasizing the importance of addressing the quality issues and providing training to auditors to improve the effectiveness and accountability of single audits.

* Medicare is a federal health insurance program designed to assist elderly and disabled beneficiaries. It covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and certain home health services. Claims are paid by a network of 49 claims administration contractors called intermediaries and carriers.
* Medicare contracting for intermediaries and carriers differs from that of most federal programs. Most federal agencies, under the Competition in Contracting Act and its implementing regulations known as the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR), generally may contract with any qualified entity for any authorized purpose so long as that entity is not debarred from government contracting and the contract is not for what is essentially a government function. Agencies are to use contractors that have a track record of successful past performance or that demonstrate a current superior ability to perform.
* Medicare, however, is authorized to deviate from the FAR under provisions of the Social Security Act enacted in 1965. For example, there is no full and open competition for intermediary or carrier contracts. Rather, intermediaries are selected in a process called nomination by provider associations, such as the American Hospital Association. When one of the local Blue plans declines to renew its subcontract, the Association nominates the replacement contractor.
* Medicare could benefit from various contracting reforms. Freeing the program to directly choose contractors on a competitive basis from a broader array of entities able to perform needed tasks would enable Medicare to benefit from efficiency and performance improvements related to competition. It also could address concerns about the dwindling number of insurers with which the program now contracts.
* Allowing Medicare to have contractors specialize in specific functions rather than assume all claims-related activities, as is the case now, also could lead to greater efficiency and better performance. For example, the agency could establish specific contractors to improve and bring uniformity to efforts to educate and respond to providers and beneficiaries, efforts that now vary widely among existing contractors.
* Functional contracting would enable CMS to select contractors that are more skilled at certain tasks and allow these contractors to concentrate on those tasks, potentially resulting in better program service. For example, the agency could establish specific contractors to improve and bring uniformity to efforts to educate and respond to providers and beneficiaries, efforts that now vary widely among existing contractors.

* IRS designed NRP to obtain new information about taxpayers' compliance with tax laws.
* While IRS is using NRP to measure voluntary filing, reporting, and payment compliance, the majority of NRP efforts are devoted to obtaining accurate voluntary reporting compliance data.
* IRS plans to use NRP data to update return selection formulas, allow IRS to design prefiling programs, and focus resources on the most significant areas of noncompliance.
* NRP's reporting compliance study consists of three major processes: casebuilding, classification, and taxpayer audits limited to those items that cannot be independently verified.
* IRS designed the casebuilding process to bring together available data to allow the agency to establish the accuracy of information reported by taxpayers on their returns.
* IRS uses the casebuilding material to determine whether an NRP audit is necessary and which items need to be verified through an audit.
* NRP audits will take place either through correspondence with the taxpayers or through face-to-face audits.
* IRS plans to conduct detailed, line-by-line audits on 1,683 of the approximately 47,000 returns in the NRP sample in order to assess the accuracy of NRP classification and, if necessary, to adjust NRP results—a process called calibration.
* One-third of the returns in the calibration sample will be returns that were classified accepted as filed (either with or without adjustments), one-third from those classified for correspondence audits, and one-third from those classified for face-to-face audits.
* None of the taxpayers with returns in the calibration sample will have been audited or otherwise contacted by IRS prior to the start of these line-by-line audits.

* IRS has reviewed NRP training materials and observed NRP classifier, correspondence examination, and field examination training sessions.

• The MHSS, a military health care system, has a medical readiness mission to provide mental health care to active-duty military personnel and dependents. The MHSS created the PDP to increase the scope of its mental health care providers, including psychiatrists and clinical psychologists. The PDP has been implemented for 7 years, and the MHSS has at least as many uniformed psychiatrists and clinical psychologists as needed to meet its readiness requirements. The PDP has demonstrated that training psychologists to prescribe drugs can reduce psychiatrists' workloads and save DOD money. The PDP has also faced implementation difficulties, including recruiting enough participants and addressing concerns about supervision. The MHSS has not decided who should supervise prescribing psychologists and is considering legislation to authorize them. The PDP has shown that training psychologists to prescribe drugs can reduce psychiatrists' workloads and save DOD money.

* The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) project is a large, deployable, infrared-optimized space telescope designed for a 5-year mission to find stars and trace galaxies from their beginning to their current formation. JWST is being developed for a 1.5 million-kilometer (936-mile) orbit around Earth. The project is divided into three major segments: the observatory segment, the ground segment, and the launch segment. JWST is being developed by Northrop Grumman, Harris, and the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). The project is currently on schedule with 8.75 months of schedule reserve remaining. The project has used schedule reserve to address technical challenges and issues. The project has used cost reserves to address risks and uncertainties. The project has used independent oversight to provide insights into project risks and manage the project.

• Experts agree that chemical facilities are among the most attractive targets for terrorists, despite the risk posed by these facilities.
• EPA regulates about 15,000 chemical facilities under the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act.
• These facilities must take a risk management plan (RMP) to prevent and prepare for accidental releases.
• Some facilities are subject to RMP requirements, while others are not.
• The RMP program helps assess security issues and develop protective programs.
• DHS is developing a plan for protecting chemical sector assets and implementing protective programs.
• The plan includes a framework for reducing the overall vulnerability of the sector.
• DHS has initiated actions to identify high-priority facilities and prioritize facilities for security.
• The plan will include background information, process, and identification of chemical sector assets.
• DHS has also initiated actions to identify critical assets, prioritize facilities, develop and implement protective programs, exchange information, and coordinate with EPA and other federal agencies.
• The plan will establish a framework for reducing the overall vulnerability of the sector in partnership with industry and state and local authorities.
• DHS has completed a draft plan in July 2004 and is working to revise it to accommodate changes to DHS’s risk management strategy and comments from stakeholders.

• The Social Security program is one of the largest federal programs in the United States, providing about $546 billion in benefits to over 49 million beneficiaries.
• Social Security Disability Insurance (DI) pays monthly cash benefits to nearly 7 million workers who have severe long-term disabilities.

• East Asian nations, including China, Japan, and South Korea, have maintained currency undervaluation policies for a period, with some countries allowing their currencies to float freely in foreign exchange markets.

• The U.S. economy has run trade deficits with East Asian countries, and the adoption of "free float" exchange rate policies may reduce U.S. trade deficits with countries in the region.

• The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has been a contentious issue since the enactment of individual income tax in 1913. Recent economic proposals aim to stimulate the economy by increasing the net capital loss limit against ordinary income. However, this measure may not be effective in stimulating aggregate demand, as it could lead to a short-term incentive to sell stocks and depress stock prices. The current rate differential between short and long-term gains and losses is approximately two to one, making it difficult to achieve full symmetry in the netting process.

* The U.S.-India "global partnership" includes economic cooperation, energy and environmental issues, democracy and development, non-proliferation and security, and high-technology and space. * India has always maintained positive relations with Iran, especially in the area of energy commerce. * New Delhi's friendship with Tehran is unlikely to become a significant obstacle to further development of U.S.-India ties. * India-Iran relations have not evolved into a strategic alliance and are unlikely to derail the further development of a U.S.-India global partnership. * New Delhi intends to bring its Iran policy into closer alignment with that of the United States. * The Bush Administration expresses strong opposition to any pipeline projects involving Iran. * Indian firms have taken long-term contracts for Iranian gas and oil, and support proposed construction of a pipeline to deliver Iranian natural gas to India through Pakistan. * The Indian government has made clear that it does not wish to see a new nuclear weapons power in the region.

• The United States has been trying to impose new import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs), which include casein and whey protein. Advocates argue that these barriers would prevent unlimited importation of milk protein, which would encourage the use of domestically produced protein and raise milk prices. Opponents counter that these imports would increase costs and result in higher retail food prices.

• The federal government first supported a program for energy storage and electric power system technology during the 1970s.
• In those early days, the program was focused mainly on energy storage—especially to even out the variable power production from rapidly growing use of wind and solar technologies—but also to support large coal and nuclear power plants.
• The advancement of computer capacity, miniaturization, and industrial controls has expanded the ability of grid operators to monitor and control electric power flows.
• The subsequent increase in networking of computerized devices for grid data collection and control advanced the ability of operators to anticipate, avoid, and otherwise mitigate potential power crises, such as blackouts.
• However, in more recent years, Internet-connected networks have become vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions, revealing a new cybersecurity challenge for electric power systems.
• The nation's energy infrastructure is diverse. It includes a variety of transmission and distribution system network structures (electricity, oil, and natural gas), an array of operating models (public and private), and a variety of hardware and software.
• The energy sector consists of thousands of electricity, oil, and natural gas assets that are dispersed geographically.
• Coordinating the security and resilience of energy assets is complicated by the virtually borderless nature of energy use and the reliance on predominantly privately-owned infrastructure.
• Key challenges and opportunities facing the electric power industry include a changing power generation mix, replacing aging infrastructure (transmission, storage, distribution, and generation); modernizing and securing communication networks (e.g., analog to digital); accommodating new end-use technologies (for solar and other distributed resources); planning for increased interdependencies of natural gas, water, and electricity systems; and devising business models to manage the challenges while providing reliable and affordable electricity.
• These activities are constrained by the need for cost control, physical security, cybersecurity, improved system resiliency, and the flexibility to adapt to weather and market uncertainties.
• Further opportunities arise from growing use of shale gas production and decreasing costs for information technologies which allow improved grid control and more opportunities for customer management of power use.

• OE supports electric grid modernization and resiliency through research and development (R&D), demonstration projects, partnerships, facilitation, modeling and analytics, and emergency preparedness and response.

* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) was enacted in 1986 to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia. It contains 10 sections covering the purposes of the bill, definitions, congressional authorization for memorials, creation of the National Capital Memorial Commission, conditions for memorial placement, site design and approval, issuance of construction permits, creation of a temporary memorial site, and other administrative provisions. * The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission, the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, the National Capital Planning Commission, the District of Columbia Historic Preservation Office, and sometimes the American Battle Monuments Commission are responsible for establishing memorials in the District of Columbia. * The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission was created in 2001 to advise the Secretary and Administrator on policy and procedures for commemorative works in the District of Columbia. * The National Capital Planning Commission was established in 1924 to implement the McMillan Plan for the District of Columbia. * The National Capital Planning Commission was renamed the National Capital Planning Commission in 1952. * The National Capital Planning Commission expanded its geographic boundaries and recognized the creation of the national capital region in Maryland and Virginia. * The National Capital Planning Commission includes 12 members, three appointed by the President, two must reside in Virginia and Maryland, and two must be residents of the District. * The National Capital Planning Commission operates under the authority of other laws for planning within the National Capital Region. * The American Battle Monuments Commission was created in 1923 to prepare plans and estimates for American cemeteries in Europe. * The American Battle Monuments Commission has statutory authority to design, construct, operate, and maintain permanent American cemeteries in foreign countries, establish and maintain U.S. military memorials, monuments, and markers, and control the design and construction of permanent U.S. military monuments and markers by other U.S. citizens and organizations.

• 35 states have established high risk health insurance pools, targeting individuals with preexisting health conditions.
• High risk pools are designed to assist individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market.
• States have a great deal of discretion in establishing and operating these pools, including covered benefits, eligibility requirements, pre-existing condition exclusion periods, and funding sources.
• States may augment premium collection with assessments on insurers, general revenue, and other state sources.
• The federal government has provided financial assistance to states during the past several years, including grants to establish high risk pools and operational grants to existing pools.
• States may elect to have the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) operate the HRPs in their states.

* The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) responsible for serving as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies. It oversees spectrum management, including the transfer of federal spectrum to commercial use, and supports the development of grants programs for public safety communications. * The NTIA leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy, including the development of long range spectrum plans and the Public Telecommunications Facilities Program. * The NTIA administers grants programs, including the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program, and works with the Rural Utilities Service to coordinate loans and grants for wireless networks. * The NTIA supports the Administration's policy goal of increasing spectrum capacity for mobile broadband services, including the development of 95 MHz of spectrum in the 1755-1850 MHz band.

• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-58) was the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in more than a decade. It included provisions for tax incentives for domestic energy production and energy efficiency, mandates to double the use of biofuels, faster procedures for energy production on federal lands, and authorization of numerous federal energy research and development programs. The Act also established the Electric Reliability Act of 2005, which required FERC to promulgate rules to create a FERC-certified ERO to improve reliability as restructuring of the U.S. bulk power system proceeds. The Act also authorized the creation of regional advisory bodies if requested by at least two-thirds of states within a region that have more than half of their electric load served within that region.

• The Robinson-Patman Act was enacted in 1936 with the purpose of creating a market atmosphere for small business to compete effectively, at least in the purchase of commodities, with larger rivals.
• The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality" where each sale is of goods purchased for resale within the United States.
• The act applies only to the sale of goods (i.e., it does not apply to the sale of services) and only where each sale is of goods purchased for resale within the United States.
• The act places burdens on American economic activity, including government enforcement of the act, which has been inconsistent with respect to R-P actions.

• The act has been applied inconsistently by the FTC, which has acted inconsistently with respect to R-P actions.

• The U.S. poverty rate in 2013 was 14.5%, the lowest since 2006.
• The SPM (Supplemental Poverty Measure) was developed in 2013 to address flaws in the "official" measure.
• The SPM includes a broader income/resource definition than the "official" measure.
• The SPM subtracts necessary expenses from resources to arrive at a measure of "disposable" income.
• The SPM income/resource thresholds are initially set at a range based on FCSU spending.
• The SPM poverty thresholds are adjusted for price differences across metropolitan and nonmetropolitan areas.
• The SPM measures the relationship of unrelated household members to others in the household.
• The SPM includes child care expenses and MOOP expenses in its poverty calculation.
• The SPM provides additional insight into the economic vulnerability of the elderly.
• The SPM captures the policy effects of child care programs and policies on child care affordability and poverty.
• The SPM is based on a broader income/resource definition than the "official" measure.

• The campus-based programs, including FSEOG, FWS, and Perkins Loan, were created to provide financial aid to students who demonstrated financial need.
• The programs operate alongside other federal student aid programs and benefit students with low-income families and those unable to obtain benefits without aid.
• The campus-based programs are unique in that they are designed to provide aid to students who demonstrate financial need, rather than based on other aid programs.
• The campus-based programs' authorizations of appropriations, along with many other provisions under the Higher Education Act, expired at the end of FY2015.

• The Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017 under the Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2015 (Extension Act; P.L. 114-105 ).
• The Extension Act prohibits future appropriations for the Perkins Loan program and prohibits an automatic extension of it under the General Education Provisions Act (GEPA; P.L. 90-247, as amended).

• The September 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have highlighted the vulnerability of water infrastructure systems in the United States.
• Water infrastructure systems are highly interconnected with other infrastructure systems, including electric power and transportation, and are critical for national water supply, transportation, and electricity infrastructure.
• Water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, and pipes that contain and transport raw water, treatment facilities that remove contaminants, and finished water reservoirs.
• Water infrastructure systems are vulnerable to terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attack.
• Water utilities have been engaged in vulnerability assessments and security improvements since the 9/11 attacks, but there is a need for more coordinated efforts and funding to address the broader security challenges.
• The Water Sector Initiative, established in 2004, aims to improve water security by coordinating federal infrastructure protection efforts and enhancing communication and coordination among stakeholders.
• The Water ISAC, a private, subscription service, provides information to water utilities and other stakeholders on security matters.
• The Water Security Channel, launched in 2004, disseminates EPA and DHS general security bulletins to more than 8, 400 utilities, state agencies, engineering firms, and researchers.
• The WaterISAC and HSIN share the goal of providing security information to water utilities, but they differ in some respects.
• The WaterISAC is a private, subscription service, while the HSIN is a free, federally funded platform for information sharing.
• The WaterISAC and HSIN have not resolved the potential for duplication and overlap among agencies, but ongoing efforts are underway to coordinate their activities.
• The WaterISAC and HSIN have not resolved the issue of inconsistent information and made the exchange of information more complicated, but they are working to resolve this issue.
• The WaterISAC and HSIN have not resolved the issue of insufficient funds for these activities, but ongoing efforts are underway to address this issue.

• Perkins IV, like previous versions of the act, requires the Secretary to reserve funds for certain purposes from funds appropriated under Section 9.

• Sections 1 through 9 deal with certain overarching provisions, such as purposes of the act (Section 2), definitions that apply throughout the act (Section 3), and authorization of appropriations (Section 9).
• Title I of the act authorizes and specifies the central provisions of the act dealing with assistance to states for career and technical education.
• Title I-A deals with allotments and allocations.
• Title I-B specifies state provisions.
• Title I-C details local provisions.

• Perkins IV, like previous versions of the act, requires the Secretary to reserve amounts for certain purposes from funds appropriated under Section 9.
• The amount reserved for assistance for outlying areas has been reduced from 0.2% of funds appropriated under Section 9 to 0.13%.
• This reduced percentage reflects the fact that two freely associated states (FASs)—Micronesia and the Marshall Islands—are no longer eligible for Perkins funding because the United States and these FASs have signed an agreement to extend their Compacts of Free Association.
• Perkins IV maintains the state allotment formula used under Perkins III unless "additional funds" are available above the FY2006 funding level.
• If funding allotted to states contains no "additional funds," the formula is unchanged.
• That is, the initial formula factors are applied, subject to the minimum grant provisions and to the provision that holds states harmless at 100% of their FY1998 grant amount.
• Assuming appropriations are level funded at the FY2006 amount, states with growing populations, such as Arizona and North Carolina, will tend to receive increased grants.
• States at their FY1998 grant amounts, such as Vermont and Wyoming, will continue to receive those grant amounts.
• Other states' grants will tend to decline, as funding shifts to states with more rapidly growing populations.

* The federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes were phased out over a 10-year period in 2001, leaving the gift tax as the only federal transfer tax in 2010. * The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 temporarily reinstated the estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes with lower top rates and larger exemptions. * The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 permanently extended the estate tax rules, except for the top tax rate, which increased to 40%. * The federal estate tax is unified as it uses the same rate structure. * The federal gift tax is a tax on gifts made during life, levied against the donor and the recipient. * The federal gift tax is reduced by the amount of estate, inheritance, legacy, or succession taxes actually paid to any state or the District of Columbia in respect to property included in the federal gross estate.

* The Bush Administration's Healthy Forests Initiative has been criticized for its high cost, which has led to increased borrowing from other accounts.
* The 2008 farm bill (P.L. 110-246) authorized the FS to provide $5 million for wood-to-energy projects, but the funding has not been used.
* The 2012 appropriations law reduced the FS funding by 9%, but the funding has not declined as much as the decline in area burned.
* The FS has been appropriated wildfire funds for fire plan research and development, but the amount of FS research funding for wildfire research is not specified.
* The FS has been appropriated wildfire funds for fire facility maintenance, but the portion used for fire facilities is unknown.

* Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees would eliminate the need for the WEP and GPO provisions of Social Security law, which are unpopular among the public and pose administrative difficulties for SSA.
* Employers might change the pension benefits of newly hired public employees to reflect the added Social Security coverage.
* The impact on overall costs to employees and governments would depend on the type of pension benefit structure governments adopt in response to mandatory participation in Social Security.
* Factors affecting this include the 6.2% Social Security payroll tax paid by employers, the 6.2% Social Security payroll tax paid by employees, the amount of employer contributions to retirement plans, and employee contributions if any.
* Pension plans for 94% of workers in frozen plans were frozen more than five years prior to the survey, and 95% of workers in frozen plans were offered a new DB pension plan.
* Increased costs might come from states operating several pension plans or several benefit structures within a single pension plan.
* Some state and local government pension plans do not have enough assets to pay 100% of promised benefits, and participants are not at risk of not receiving their promised benefits in the short or medium term.
* Potential sources of funding to make up for shortfalls include state or local general revenues, increased contributions from current employees, and greater returns on pension plan investments.
* The impact would likely be minimal in plans that have sufficient assets to pay 100% of promised benefits, but increased contributions from current employees might add financial strain to pension systems that are currently underfunded and do not have sufficient assets.
* Some argue that mandatory coverage would impose significant administrative burdens on state and local governments, while opponents argue that it would raise constitutional issues and be challenging in court.
* Non-covered state and local government workers should share in providing the poverty reduction that occurs through Social Security, which redistributes income from higher-earning workers to lower-earning workers.
* Supporters of mandatory Social Security coverage argue that, if most non-covered state and local government employees will qualify for Social Security benefits based on a second job or a spouse's employment, they should be required to pay into the Social Security system throughout their careers.
* Opponents of mandatory coverage maintain that Social Security benefit reductions under the WEP and GPO already take into account that some workers participate in alternative public pension plans that operate outside of Social Security.

* TAA (Trade Adjustment Assistance) provides federal assistance to workers who involuntarily lose their jobs due to foreign competition. Eligible workers receive funding for training and reemployment services, as well as income support while enrolled in training. TAA eligibility is limited to workers who are adversely affected by reduced trade barriers and increased trade. TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA, Title IV of P.L. 114-27). The eligibility and benefit provisions of TAARA are authorized to continue through June 30, 2021. TAA was created in 1962 and, historically, has been reauthorized alongside expansionary trade policies. A detailed legislative history of the program is in the Appendix. In June 2015, TAA was reauthorized by TAARA. The eligibility and benefit provisions of TAARA are authorized to continue through June 30, 2021. TAA was jointly administered by the federal government and the states. It is funded by the federal government. The respective roles of federal and state governments in administering and financing the TAA program were in place prior to TAARA and were not substantively changed by the reauthorization law. TAA is jointly administered by the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) and cooperating state agencies. DOL makes group eligibility determinations, allots appropriated funds to cooperating state agencies, and oversees grantees. Individual benefits are provided through state workforce systems and state unemployment insurance systems. Workers may physically receive benefits and services through local American Job Centers (also known as One-Stop Career Centers). States are responsible for collecting participation and outcome data and reporting these data to DOL. The Health Coverage Tax Credit, which is available to qualified TAA-certified workers who purchase qualified health insurance, is administered by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). It is administered separately from the TAA program's other benefits and services. TAA is funded by mandatory appropriations. Typically, Congress appropriates a single sum that supports all TAA activities. DOL then allocates these funds to various program activities. Under TAARA, funding for training and reemployment services is capped at $450 million per year. These funds are allotted to the states via a grant allocation formula that considers past and anticipated program usage. States may expend training and reemployment service funds in the year of allotment or in either of the next two fiscal years. Training subsidies are states'

• The Federal Employee Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004 established the Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP), which provides supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.
• FEDVIP covers both nationwide and overseas dental and vision plans, with premiums varying by plan, geographic area, and residency.
• Individuals can enroll in FEDVIP through the Internet or by calling 1-877-888-FEDS.
• FEDVIP premiums are pre-tax for employees, with premiums for dental and vision services being secondary payers.
• Individuals must weigh coverage, use, and premiums against their risk aversion and financial situation.
• FEDVIP premiums and FSA contributions are pre-tax for employees, allowing individuals to decide whether to enroll in dental or vision plans.
• Individuals can use FSA funds for any copayments, coinsurance amounts, deductibles, amounts exceeding annual or lifetime maximums, or amounts above plan payment for out-of-network services.
• Individuals can "wait and see" and use FSA funds for other qualified medical expenses if they do not use dental or vision services.
• Individuals can choose to enroll only in FEDVIP and minimize out-of-pocket expenditures by staying in-network.

* Mandatory reporting of livestock prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb is required under the Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (P.L. 106-78, Title IX; LMR). The law requires that meat packers report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). Authority for mandatory reporting expired on September 30, 2015. The law requires that producers submit required information voluntarily, and producers can support a national consensus bill to preempt emerging patchwork state price reporting laws. The law also requires USDA to conduct a study on the effects of mandatory reporting on the livestock market.

* The United States Constitution does not provide for or authorize the recall of any United States officials, including Senators, Representatives, or the President or Vice President.
* Members of Congress may have their services ended by their resignation, death, or by action of the House of Representatives in which they sit by way of an expulsion or by a finding that a subsequent public office accepted by a Member is "incompatible" with congressional office.
* The Senate has the authority to censure or otherwise discipline its Members for any conduct that the Senate finds to be reprehensible and/or to reflect discredit on the institution and which is, therefore, worthy of rebuke or condemnation.
* A censure by the Senate, whereby the full Senate adopts by majority vote a formal resolution of disapproval of a Member, may encompass conduct that does not violate any express state or federal law, nor any specific Rule of the Senate.
* The authority to expel would thus be used cautiously when the institution of Congress might be seen as usurping or supplanting its own institutional judgment for the judgment of the electorate as to the character or fitness for office of an individual whom the people have chosen to represent them in Congress.
* The required qualifications, as well as the disqualifications, to serve in Congress were intentionally kept at a minimum by the framers of the Constitution to allow the people broad discretion to send whom they wish to represent them in Congress.
* Officers and employees of the United States, including Members of Congress, do not forfeit the federal pensions for which they qualify if convicted of a federal crime which relates to disclosure of classified information, espionage, sabotage, treason, misprision of treason, rebellion or insurrection, seditious conspiracy, harboring or concealing persons, gathering or transmitting defense information, perjury in relation to those offenses, and other designated offenses relating to secrets and national security offenses against the United States.
* The forfeiture provisions of this law will apply if the criminal misconduct was engaged in while the individual was a Member of Congress (or while the individual was the President, Vice President, or an elected official of a state or local government), and if every element of the offense "directly relates to the performance of the individual's official duties as a Member, the President, the Vice President, or an elected official of a State or local government."

• The presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and in the scientific workforce has been and continues to be of concern to some in the scientific community.
• Enrollment of U.S. citizens in graduate science and engineering programs has not kept pace with that of foreign students in those programs.
• A significant number of university faculty in the scientific disciplines are foreign, and foreign doctorates are employed in large numbers by industry.
• Those in the scientific community, arguing for ceilings on admissions for immigrants, maintain that foreign students use U.S. graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration through sponsorships for legal permanent residence.
• Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the United States, with many eventually becoming citizens.
• Data on adjustments from temporary visas to permanent status reveal that approximately 6 in 10 new permanent residents occurred in both 2007 and 2008 from adjustments of status admissions.
• In 2008, approximately 15.0% of those awarded legal permanent resident status resulted from employment-based preferences.
• Few will dispute that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers.
• There are charges that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers.
• The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that between the years 2006 and 2016, employment in science and engineering fields will increase at a faster rate than other professional groups.
• The growth rate will result, primarily, from growth in mathematics and computer-related occupations.
• The H-1B temporary admissions program claims a nationwide shortage of scientists and engineers.
• A report of the National Science Foundation (NSF) during the late 1980s claiming a nationwide shortage of scientists and engineers may have contributed to the decision by Congress to expand the skilled-labor preference system contained in the Immigration Act of 1990.
• The 1990 legislation more than doubled employment-based immigration, including scientists and engineers entering under the H-1B visa category.
• The legislation ascribed high priority to the entry of selected skilled and professional workers, and simplified admissions procedures for foreign nationals seeking to temporarily work, study, or conduct business in the United States.
